excerpt: Papal palace, once rival to the Vatican, with 25 open rooms, frescoes & cultural events.
detail_description: The Palais des Papes, once a rival to the Vatican, is an imposing structure consisting of two different parts: the severe Palais Vieux and the more decorative Palais Nouveau. The interiors are austere due to the loss of original furnishings during history, but visitors can still imagine its medieval splendor with colorful frescoes and grand halls. The palace hosts cultural events in its beautiful courtyard, showcasing performances in various languages.
name: Palais des Papes

excerpt: Avignon, a city in southeastern France’s Provence region, is set on the Rhône River. From 1309 to 1377, it was the seat of the Catholic popes. It remained under papal rule until becoming part of France in 1791. This legacy can be seen in the massive Palais des Papes (Popes' Palace) in the city center, which is surrounded by medieval stone ramparts.
detail_description: Avignon, a city in the Provence region of southeastern France, sits on the banks of the Rhône River. It was once the seat of the Catholic popes from 1309 to 1377 and remained under papal rule until it became part of France in 1791. The city's rich history is evident in landmarks like the imposing Palais des Papes (Popes' Palace) and medieval stone ramparts that surround it.
name: Avignon

detail_description: Rocher des Doms is a must-visit in Avignon, along with the Palais des Papes and the University. This beautiful garden offers a panoramic view of the city and its surroundings. The city of Avignon is investing in restoring this historic garden to its former glory, originally designed by Jean-Pierre Barillet-Deschamps. It's an ideal place for a leisurely stroll and to admire the Avignon bridge from a different perspective.
name: Rocher des Doms

excerpt: Storied indoor market with a vertical garden, cafes & stalls selling local produce, meats & cheeses.
detail_description: Les Halles d'Avignon, also known as Avignon Market Halls or Central Halls, is a historic indoor market located on Pie Square in the heart of Avignon. This vibrant marketplace features a variety of stalls offering high-quality local produce, meats, cheeses, breads, pastries, shellfish, flowers and more.
name: Les Halles d'Avignon

excerpt: Grand 1300s bishop's residence housing works by early Renaissance masters, including Botticelli.
detail_description: The Musée du Petit Palais, located in Avignon, is a museum and art gallery housed in a 14th-century building that was once the residence of bishops. It features an impressive collection of early Renaissance paintings from Italy as well as works from the Avignon school. The museum's holdings include Italian primitive paintings, stone carvings, and sculptures from the Middle Ages and Renaissance.
name: Musée du Petit Palais
address: Palais des archevêques, Pl. du Palais, 84000 Avignon, France

excerpt: 12th-century cathedral, crowned by a gilded statue of Virgin Mary, with tombs of the Avignon popes.
detail_description: Avignon Cathedral, also known as Cathedrale Notre-Dame des Doms d'Avignon, is a 12th-century Romanesque-style building located next to the Papal Palace. The cathedral is adorned with a gilded statue of the Virgin Mary and is a UNESCO Heritage Site. Its elevated position on a rocky ledge allows it to be visible from various points in the city and beyond.
name: Notre Dame des Doms

excerpt: Esprit Calvet's collection, with Egyptian, Greek & Roman artifacts, archeology & European paintings.
detail_description: Musée Calvet, located in Avignon, has been open to the public for over 200 years. It was founded by local doctor and collector Esprit Calvet who donated his diverse collection of art, library, and curiosities to the city. The museum's collection includes ancient archaeology, fine art, decorative art, and ethnological artifacts from Oceania, Asia, and Africa. Notable attractions include an Egyptology department with a sarcophagus and offering table.
name: Musée Calvet

excerpt: The city's main square houses the town hall & opera and boasts open-air cafes & restaurants.
detail_description: Pl. de l'Horloge is the bustling main square in Avignon, featuring the town hall and opera house, as well as a plethora of open-air cafes and restaurants. It serves as a gateway to the 13th-century perimeter of Avignon, leading visitors north towards Pont Saint Benezet.
name: Pl. de l'Horloge

excerpt: Rue des Teinturiers is a bohemian district surrounding the street of the same name, which runs alongside a small canal with centuries-old waterwheels. Alternative theaters such as Le Petit Chien and Au Magasin present comedy and dance. Hip wine bars and upscale Provençal brasseries are tucked into leafy courtyards, and tree-shaded cobblestone alleys are dotted with vintage clothing shops and cool art galleries.
detail_description: Rue des Teinturiers is located in a bohemian district with a charming street running alongside a small canal adorned with centuries-old waterwheels. The area is home to alternative theaters like Le Petit Chien and Au Magasin, offering comedy and dance performances. Visitors can explore hip wine bars, upscale Provençal brasseries nestled in leafy courtyards, and cobblestone alleys lined with vintage clothing shops and art galleries.
name: Rue des Teinturiers

excerpt: Narrow, cobblestone road hugging the Canal de Vaucluse featuring theaters, cafes & water wheels.
detail_description: Rue des Teinturiers is a charming, narrow cobblestone street that winds alongside the picturesque Canal de Vaucluse. This historic thoroughfare was once bustling with textile production, particularly silk manufacturing from the 14th to the 19th century, powered by an impressive array of water wheels—though only four remain today. Locals affectionately refer to it as 'the street of wheels.'
name: Rue des Teinturiers

excerpt: Over 700 hectares of greenery area in the Rhône river with paths and a rich wild animal life.
detail_description: Located in the Rhône river, the Île de la Barthelasse spans over 700 hectares of lush greenery and is home to a diverse wildlife population. Just a short boat ride away from Avignon's bustling city center, this island offers a tranquil escape with its scenic pathways and picturesque picnic spots. Visitors can explore the island on foot or by bike, taking in stunning views of the Palace of the Popes and Pont Saint-Benezet along the way.
name: île de la Barthelasse

detail_description: In the heart of Avignon's historic center lies the bustling Place de l'Horloge, a lively square surrounded by charming boutiques, restaurants, cafes, and bars. The pedestrianized area to the southeast and narrow streets to the west offer excellent boutique shopping experiences. Visitors can enjoy people-watching at the numerous cafes while savoring light lunches at popular spots like Phimabri.
name: Place de l’Horloge

excerpt: Leafy public gardens atop a hill, featuring a pond, a cafe & views of the river & countryside.
detail_description: Jardin des Doms is a picturesque public garden located on a hill in Avignon, offering stunning views of the Rhone River and the countryside. The park features a pond, a cafe, tall trees, fountains, and sculptures, making it an ideal place for leisurely strolls while enjoying the panoramic scenery. Visitors can access the garden for free during its opening hours from 7:30 AM to 8 PM.
name: Jardin des Doms

excerpt: Paintings, drawing & sculptures by legendary artists showcased in an 18th-century mansion.
detail_description: Musée Angladon is a captivating museum located in an elegant 18th-century mansion in Avignon, France. It showcases an impressive collection of major 18th- to 20th-century paintings and decorative arts assembled by the renowned Parisian couturier Jacques Doucet. Visitors can admire works by celebrated artists such as Degas, van Gogh, Manet, Cezanne, Modigliani, and Picasso.
name: Musée Angladon

excerpt: In 2000 Yves Lambert opened this museum to share his private art collection with the public.
detail_description: Nestled just 300 meters from the Porte de la Republique, the Collection Lambert Avignon is a contemporary art museum that invites visitors to explore an impressive array of modern artworks. Established in 2000 by renowned art collector Yvon Lambert, this cultural gem occupies two stunning 18th-century buildings in the heart of Avignon.
name: Collection Lambert Avignon

excerpt: Small museum in a 17th-century church exhibiting Greek, Roman & Etruscan sculptures, vases & glass.
detail_description: Nestled within a charming 17th-century Jesuit chapel, the Musée Lapidaire in Avignon is a hidden gem for history enthusiasts and art lovers alike. This small yet captivating museum showcases an impressive collection of Greek, Roman, and Etruscan sculptures, alongside artifacts from Gallo-Roman times. Visitors can marvel at intricately inscribed slabs and fascinating shabtis—small statues meant to accompany the deceased into the afterlife.
name: Musée Lapidaire
address: 27 Rue de la République, 84000 Avignon, France

excerpt: Cobbled Renaissance-era plaza, flanked by signature examples of 17th-century baroque architecture.
detail_description: Pl. du Palais is a charming cobbled plaza in Avignon, surrounded by stunning 17th-century baroque architecture. The highlight is the roof offering breathtaking views of the Cathedral and the city center. Visitors can explore the palace on a self-guided tour with an interesting audio guide. This historic square stands as a testament to Avignon's rich medieval past as the seat of papal power in the 14th century.
name: Pl. du Palais

detail_description: Pl. des Corps Saints is one of the top spots in Avignon for enjoying a vibrant nightlife scene, with its array of bars, cafes, and brasseries. Situated just behind the Tourist Office, this lively area offers a great atmosphere for socializing and unwinding. Whether you're looking to savor local cuisine or sip on refreshing drinks, Pl. des Corps Saints has something to offer every visitor seeking an enjoyable evening out in Avignon.
name: Pl. des Corps Saints

excerpt: Ruins of famous medieval bridge, with 4 arches spanning the Rhone & a small chapel to St Nicholas.
detail_description: The Bridge of Avignon, also known as Pont Saint-Benezet, is a famous medieval bridge with four arches spanning the Rhone River and featuring a small chapel dedicated to St. Nicholas. Located in the culturally rich city of Avignon in the Provence region, this historic site is just one of five UNESCO world heritage sites in the area.
name: The Bridge of Avignon
address: Bd de la Ligne, 84000 Avignon, France

excerpt: Small Provençal Gothic cathedral dating to 1358, featuring carved walnut doors & interior artworks.
detail_description: Located in Avignon, the Basilique Saint-Pierre is a small Provençal Gothic cathedral with a rich history dating back to 1358. This minor basilica was built on the site of an earlier 7th-century church dedicated to Saint Peter and features intricate carved walnut doors and interior artworks. The church showcases architectural elements from the 14th, 15th, and 16th centuries, offering visitors a glimpse into its evolving design over time.
name: Basilique Saint-Pierre

excerpt: Fortress-like stone walls built around the city in the 14th century, with views of the Rhone River.
detail_description: The Remparts d'Avignon, a remarkable set of fortified walls encircling the historic city of Avignon in southern France, stand as a testament to medieval architecture and defense. Constructed between 1355 and 1370 during the papacy, these impressive stone walls stretch over 4 kilometers and rise about 8 meters high.
name: Remparts d'Avignon

excerpt: 14th-century fortress on a hill with gardens, walking paths & mountain & city views.
detail_description: Nestled on a hill overlooking the picturesque city of Avignon, Fort Saint-André is a remarkable 14th-century fortress that invites visitors to step back in time. This architectural marvel showcases medieval military design with its formidable towers, portcullises, and drawbridge. As you wander through its well-preserved grounds, you'll be captivated by the stunning gardens and walking paths that offer breathtaking views of both the mountains and the city below.
name: Fort Saint-André
address: 57A Rue Mnt du Fort, 30400 Villeneuve-lès-Avignon, France

excerpt: Genteel suites in a storied mansion, plus an outdoor pool, a spa & views of the Palais des Papes.
detail_description: La Divine Comédie is an upscale boutique bed and breakfast located in Avignon, France. It offers a storied mansion with genteel suites, an outdoor pool, a spa, and views of the Palais des Papes. The property boasts the largest private garden in Avignon with mature trees and lush palms, providing a tranquil setting for guests to relax.
name: La Divine Comédie
address: 16 Imp. Jean Pierre Gras, 84000 Avignon, France

excerpt: Medieval Villeneuve-lès-Avignon lies on the Rhône river beneath the imposing hilltop Fort St.-André, with its well-preserved 14th-century battlements. The Chartreuse de Villeneuve lez Avignon convent has peaceful cloisters and an arts center, and Musée Pierre-de-Luxembourg shows religious art. Saturday market Marché et Brocante sells antiques and food, while delis and al fresco Provençal bistros dot cobbled streets.
detail_description: Villeneuve-lès-Avignon is a charming medieval town located on the Rhône river, just a short walk from Avignon. The town boasts an impressive architectural heritage, including the well-preserved 14th-century battlements of Fort St.-André and the peaceful cloisters of Chartreuse de Villeneuve lez Avignon convent.
name: Villeneuve-lès-Avignon

detail_description: Place Crillon is a stunning square in Avignon that offers a perfect blend of history and charm. This baroque-style plaza, once known as Place du Limas, has evolved over the centuries and now serves as a chic spot to unwind with a glass of bubbly or enjoy a leisurely coffee break. Strolling through its pedestrian streets leads you to the enchanting Rue des Teinturiers, where the iconic wooden wheels turn gracefully alongside the Sorgue River's resurgences.
name: Place Crillon

excerpt: Buzzing Place Pie centers on its namesake square and the Marché les Halles d'Avignon, with stalls offering Provençal rosé wines and olives. A Sunday flea market on Place des Carmes sells vintage clothes and secondhand books. Musée Angladon – Collection Jacques Doucet showcases artists like Dégas and Picasso, and stately Théâtre des Halles stages classical concerts. Al fresco bars and busy brasseries dot the streets.
detail_description: Place Pie is a vibrant square in the heart of Avignon, known for its bustling Marché les Halles d'Avignon offering Provençal rosé wines and olives. The area also hosts a popular Sunday flea market at Place des Carmes, where visitors can find vintage clothes and secondhand books. Art enthusiasts can explore Musée Angladon – Collection Jacques Doucet to admire works by renowned artists such as Dégas and Picasso.
name: Place Pie

detail_description: The Laurette Théâtre Festival Avignon OFF offers a unique experience by combining the magic of theater with delicious cuisine, creating a theatrical dining setting. The venue features two rooms, one with 100 seats and another smaller one, both known for their excellent welcome and diverse programming. Visitors can enjoy plays like 'Never on the First Night' in this vibrant theatrical atmosphere, making it a memorable and enjoyable experience for theater enthusiasts.
name: Laurette Théâtre Festival Avignon OFF

excerpt: Old-school natural history museum with 3 floors of zoological & botanical specimens & fossils.
detail_description: Musée Requien is a quaint natural history museum located in Avignon, France. It features three floors filled with zoological and botanical specimens, fossils, and striking visual displays that are sure to captivate children. The museum is named after local naturalist Espirt Requien and serves as an entrance to one of the most important natural history libraries in France. Although all signage is in French only and there's no audio guide available, admission is free.
name: Musée Requien

detail_description: Located in the heart of Avignon, the Opéra Grand Avignon is a historic Italian-style theater dating back to the 19th century. With a capacity for over 700 people, it is a prominent venue for performances, especially during the renowned summer festival. The opera has undergone extensive renovations and restorations to ensure comfort and excellent visibility for its audiences. Its rich history and architectural beauty make it an essential stop for visitors exploring the city's cultural landmarks.
name: Opéra Grand Avignon

detail_description: Avignon TGV is a modern and well-maintained high-speed train station in France, serving as a major arrival point for travelers from cities like Nice, Marseille, and Paris. The station offers clean facilities with informative screens for train positioning and arrivals. While the food options are somewhat limited and slightly expensive, the station provides frequent shuttle trains to the city center. Additionally, it features rental car services that offer a straightforward process for travelers.
name: Avignon TGV

excerpt: Elegantly plated entrees, desserts & wine in a homey venue with a terrace in front.
detail_description: Restaurant Fou de Fafa is a cozy and popular dining spot in Avignon, run by a British couple who are passionate about providing delicious meals. The restaurant offers an intimate and picturesque setting with a relaxed atmosphere. The menu features simple yet exquisite dishes, from sumptuous vegetable carpaccio to perfectly seared duck breast, all beautifully presented. The carefully selected wine list complements the delightful cuisine.
name: Restaurant Fou de Fafa
address: 17 Rue Des Trois Faucons, 84000 Avignon, France

detail_description: Avignon Gourmet Tours offers a delightful way to explore the city's culinary traditions and main sights. The Taste of Avignon morning tour provides a perfect introduction, taking visitors to charming local shops to sample delicious delicacies. With an infectious passion for the city and its small businesses, the guide ensures an engaging experience. The tour also covers the extensive pedestrian zone, offering practical tips and insights while exploring historic monuments like the Palace of the Popes.
name: Avignon Gourmet Tours

detail_description: The Festival d'Avignon is a renowned international event that showcases artists from around the world, with performances in various languages including French, Arabic, Persian, Greek, Chinese, Zulu, Portuguese, Spanish, Italian, English and more. The festival features a diverse lineup of artists from the Middle East and North Africa. Taking place in July in Avignon, France, it is one of the largest performing arts events in the country.
name: Festival d'Avignon
address: Cloître Saint-Louis, 20 Rue du Portail Boquier, 84000 Avignon, France

detail_description: Maison Violette in Saint Agricol, Avignon is a delightful bakery offering a variety of delectable pastries and breads. Visitors can enjoy freshly baked croissants, eclairs, and lattes for a quick breakfast before starting their day. The bakery also serves delicious sandwiches and other lunch options that patrons can take with them.
name: Maison Violette | Saint Agricol

detail_description: Pl. Saint-Didier is a charming square located in the heart of Aix-en-Provence, France. It is known for its lively atmosphere, surrounded by quaint cafes and restaurants where visitors can enjoy delicious local cuisine. The square is also home to a beautiful fountain and is a popular spot for people-watching and soaking up the vibrant ambiance of the city. With its picturesque surroundings and bustling energy, Pl. Saint-Didier offers a delightful experience for both locals and tourists alike.
name: Pl. Saint-Didier

detail_description: Orange Mistral 7 is a store known for its exceptional customer service. Visitors praise the professionalism, attentiveness, and humor of the staff, particularly mentioning Najate's excellent assistance. The team is described as welcoming and patient in addressing inquiries with efficiency and expertise. Customers also appreciate the personalized service provided by the manager, Samir, who is commended for his knowledge and ability to tailor solutions to individual needs.
name: Orange
address: CENTRE COMMERCIAL AUCHAN MISTRAL 7, 1741 Rte de Marseille, 84140 Avignon, France

excerpt: Decorative arts from the 17th & 18th centuries, displayed in an elegant mansion with a back garden.
detail_description: The Musée Louis Vouland, located in a charming mansion on Rue Victor Hugo, showcases an exquisite collection of 17th and 18th-century decorative arts. This museum was established following the bequest of local businessman Louis Vouland, who was passionate about collecting fine art and requested that his townhouse and cherished collection be open to the public.
name: Musée Louis Vouland

excerpt: This 7th-century Gothic Roman Catholic church features a bell tower & a baroque altar.
detail_description: The Church of Saint-Agricol is a beautiful and atmospheric church in Avignon. The priest and deacon were both very welcoming and the atmosphere was quiet.
name: Church of Saint-Agricol

detail_description: The synagogue in Avignon is a beautiful and historic house of worship. It is one of the oldest synagogues in France and it is still active today. The synagogue features an interesting interior dome roof that was unique for its time. Women are allowed to sit in the balcony during services, which makes it a very welcoming place for visitors. The history of the Papal Jews and the synagogue itself is fascinating, and well worth a visit for anyone interested in Jewish culture.
name: Synagogue d'Avignon

excerpt: 14th-century Gothic-style Catholic church with Renaissance art & a working bell tower.
detail_description: Nestled in the heart of Avignon, the Église Saint Didier is a stunning example of 14th-century Gothic architecture that invites visitors to step back in time. Constructed between 1356 and 1359, this single-aisled church boasts thick stone walls and an expansive nave that creates a sense of grandeur. Notably, it houses one of France's earliest Renaissance artworks—the Way of the Cross by Francesco Laurana—crafted between 1478 and 1481.
name: Église Saint Didier

detail_description: The Hôtel des Monnaies is a prominent historical edifice that has stood the test of time. This architectural masterpiece holds great significance due to its rich history and cultural value. Situated in a prime location, it serves as an emblematic symbol of the past, showcasing remarkable craftsmanship and design. The Hôtel des Monnaies has witnessed centuries of change and remains an enduring testament to human ingenuity.
name: Hôtel des monnaies
address: 37 Rue Mnt de la Tour, 30400 Villeneuve-lès-Avignon, France

detail_description: The Chapel of the Oratory, seen from outside, exudes grandeur and splendor. Its porch adorned with an image of the Virgin Mary beckons one to enter. Unfortunately, it was closed during a visit, eliciting a hint of disappointment. This magnificent chapel boasts an oval dome and will soon host a captivating exhibition showcasing contemporary art in September.
name: Chapelle de l'Oratoire

detail_description: The theater "Theatre of the Rampart" is a nice, small theater with French content. It's fun to watch a play once and it's also great for learning about the French language.
name: Théâtre du Rempart

detail_description: Église Notre-Dame-des-Anges de L'Isle-sur-la-Sorgue is a 17th-century Romanesque church located in the heart of the town. While its exterior may seem simplistic, the interior boasts intricately carved woodwork and a richly gilded altarpiece. The church's history dates back to 1212 when a collegiate church was founded under its patronage.
name: Église Notre-Dame-des-Anges de L'Isle-sur-la-Sorgue
address: Pl. de la Liberté, 84800 L'Isle-sur-la-Sorgue, France

detail_description: Le Grenier à sel in Avignon is a recent addition to the city's vibrant arts scene. Housed in an 18th-century building that was once a salt store, it now serves as an exhibition and performance space with a focus on exploring the connections between art, science, and technology. The venue offers excellent programming and is conveniently located near the ramparts with ample parking. While the exhibitions may be brief due to limited resources, visitors can expect a pleasant reception.
name: Le Grenier à sel

detail_description: Théâtre des Halles is a renowned French theater in Avignon, Vaucluse, established in 1983 by director Alain Timar. It serves as a permanent stage and venue for the Festival off d'Avignon and is conveniently situated within the city walls near Place Pie and the Halles d'Avignon market. The theater offers a pleasant ambiance with excellent acoustics and visibility from any seat, complemented by a beautifully restored garden.
name: Théâtre des Halles
address: Rue du Roi René, 84000 Avignon, France

name: Château Saint Pierre d'Escarvaillac
address: de la Muscadelle, 215, Chemin de Saint-Pierre, Chem. de Bonpas, 84140 Avignon, France
